Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Nonlinear Vibration Absorbers for Multi-Frequency Excitation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is to investigate dynamic interactions in systems composed of multiple vibration absorbers that are tuned to different frequencies. Most tuned absorber devices are designed to reduce vibrations near a given frequency, typically to suppress the resonance of a troublesome vibration mode. If one uses a set of absorbers tuned to different frequencies, for example, to address multiple vibration modes, nonlinear dynamic interactions between absorbers can occur, causing a significant reduction in the effectiveness of the absorber system. Thus, optimal design of multi-frequency absorber systems requires a fundamental understanding of these interactions, so that they can be avoided. The research program is aimed at developing this knowledge base and implementing it to reduce multi-frequency automotive powertrain torsional vibrations that occur, for example, in engines that employ cylinder deactivation. The approach involves a combination of physical modeling, analysis by perturbation methods and computer simulations, experimental verification, and development of guidelines for meeting performance specifications by selection of absorber system parameters, specifically, tunings and inertias.

The results obtained will extend the knowledge base for vibration absorbers to situations with multi-frequency excitations, which will allow for improved effectiveness of absorber systems over a wide range of operating conditions. The university and industrial partners will work in close cooperation to develop absorber systems that will facilitate the implementation of fuel-saving technologies for automotive engines, by allowing them to operate in regimes with high efficiency that are otherwise plagued with vibration problems. The results of the research will be made widely accessible by technical publications and presentations. The research activity will also be described, in the general context of energy conservation technologies, by the university PIs and their graduate students in summer outreach programs geared to middle and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT:  During the course of this NSF program, the team of researchers from MIchigan State University and FCA (Fiat Chrysler Automobiles) developed tools for predicting the behavior and effectiveness of vibration absorbers in environments where they are subjected to loading patterns that involve multiple frequencies.  These absorbers have direct application to torsional (twisting) vibrations in automotive engines and drivetrain components and their implementation has the potential to enhance fuel-saving technologies such as cylinder deactivation and low-speed, high-torque operation.  The challenging aspect of these problems is that absorbers tuned to address vibrations at different frequencies can exhibit complicated interactions that need to be understood and predicted in order to develop optimal designs.  This project provided predictive mathematical tools for this class of problems and verified them with experimental studies.  The results show that one cannot simply design individual absorber elements by separately considering the relevant frequencies, but that a fully integrated design that accounts for frequency interactions is necessary.  Furthermore, the results show that one can actually take advantage of these interactions to develop systems that have less mass than would be required by a naive design approach.  In addition, the project developed predictive tools for describing the effects of gravity on rotating absorber systems, and for absorber systems that utilize translation and rocking of absorber masses to increase their effective inertia, thereby offering improved performance for a given packaging space and absorber mass.  In summary, the results obtained are valuable from both fundamental and applied perspectives.

BROADER IMPACTS: The Broader Impacts of this project include all the potential societal benefits associated with improved fuel economy of automotive engines.  Also, the project was a collaboration between theoreticians, experimentalists, and industry.  The project involved training of graduate students and REU-supported undergraduate students, all of whom obtained their degrees and went on to work in the automotive industry or continued in graduate school.  All students gained broad experience through systematic studies involving modeling, mathematical analysis, computational analysis, and experiments.  In addition, the close interactions with industry provided them with valuable practical perspective about their research.  In terms of technology transfer, FCA developed an experimental four-cylinder engine with many fuel saving measures, including pendulum absorbers that were designed using the expertise developed by FCA over the course of the FCA/MSU collaboration. The work led to several journal publications and a number of talks at national and international meetings.
